definition: the philosophy of materialism, doctrine that physical matter is the whole of reality
abbr. for 論語|论语[Lun2 yu3], The Analects (of Confucius)
opinion/view/theory/doctrine/to discuss/to talk about/to regard/to consider/per/by the (kilometer, hour etc)

sentences.english: The body that he, the materialist, had treated so contumeliously took its revenge on him.
sentences.chinese: 這位唯物論者曾極度蔑視肉體，如今肉體對他了報復。
唯心論和唯物論是對立的。

sentences.english: You have to go to materialism and dialectics.
sentences.chinese: 你必須採取唯物論和辯證法的方法。

sentences.english: The theory of traditional Chinese medicine has been deeply influenced by classical Chinese materialism and dialectics .
sentences.chinese: 中醫藥學受古代唯物論和辯證法的深刻影響。

sentences.english: Anti- materialists tend to deride the importance of "things."
sentences.chinese: 反唯物論者往往會瞧不起物質的重要性。

sentences.english: Your lawyers are always so materialistic.
sentences.chinese: 你們律師總是唯物論者。

sentences.english: We must study dialectical materialism so that we can use it to guide our work.
sentences.chinese: 我們要認真學習辯證唯物論，用以指導實踐。

sentences.english: I am hardworking and am non-materialistic.
sentences.chinese: 我是勤勉和上午非唯物論。

sentences.english: VOICE: Is he saying that all science is materialistic or atheistic ?
sentences.chinese: 那他是說所有的科學都是唯物論或是無神論的？

sentences.english: From the viewpoint of the dialectical materialism, form and content are not separated.
sentences.chinese: 按照辯證唯物論的觀點，形式和內容是不可分離的。

sentences.english: Spiritualism, then, suitably stands opposed to materialism.
sentences.chinese: 唯心論，那麼，適當地站在反對唯物論。

sentences.english: Over the past several years, the momentum has shifted away from hard-core materialism. The brain seems less like a cold machine.
sentences.chinese: 在過去的幾年中，絕對唯物論大勢已去。

definition: slave-owning society (precedes feudal society 封建社會|封建社会 in Marxist theory)
lit. view a text and interpret (idiom); to interpret word by word without understanding the meaning/a far-fetched interpretation
Jian Zoupianfeng, pseudonym of prolific modern novelist
the sword moves with side stroke (modern idiom)/fig. unexpected winning move/unconventional gambit
philosophy of idealism, the doctrine that external reality is a product of consciousness
